head.title: An American Town Meeting: The Issue Is Race; The Cubans

hedline.hl1: An American Town Meeting: The Issue Is Race; The Cubans

abstract.p: Robert Cone letter, responding to June 5 article Best of Friends, Worlds Apart, in series How Race Is Lived in America, confirms absence of racism in Cuba

block.p: Your June 5 front-page article about two Cuban refugees, one black and one white, whose friendship in Cuba erodes in the United States confirms an impression I got from a short stay in Havana: that the American brand of racism is absent in Cuba.
Light- and dark-skinned families live together in the same apartment buildings and share the same jobs and social world.

Your June 5 front-page article about two Cuban refugees, one black and one white, whose friendship in Cuba erodes in the United States confirms an impression I got from a short stay in Havana: that the American brand of racism is absent in Cuba.
Light- and dark-skinned families live together in the same apartment buildings and share the same jobs and social world.
People on the sidewalk or in restaurants were a random mix to such a degree that after a while we stopped being aware of anybody's skin color at all.

Perhaps this short sampling does not tell the whole story, but it seems odd that the United States can overlook human rights violations in China and not consider that in the human right to have good race relations, Cuba is ahead of the United States.
